--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Derek James wrote:
> 
> >--- Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> Umm well does NEAT implement indirect encoding? I would say it was 
> direct because each gene is expressed directly within a a network.

I think Derek's point was that the NEAT method of historical markings,
speciation, and starting with a minimal genome can in principle be
applied to any encoding.  It's true that the encoding that I used in
my papers and software is direct, but (Derek can correctly me if I'm
wrong) I think Derek is anticipating in the future being able to
change the encoding without having to write an entirely new system, 
thereby eventually getting indirect versions of NEAT.

If what I'm saying sounds strange, consider that the NEAT method says
nothing about the *mapping* between genotype and phenotype. So NEAT
genes could e.g. encode proteins or cell splitting rules.

(I know at least one person has already written an indirect NEAT.)

ken
